resources.string:
What is family planning? 

 What is contraception? 

 Why is birth control important? 

 I am married why is family planning important for me?
What is most important to you?
How comfortable and how easy it is to use.
If your partner is willing to use family planning, or if you must keep its use hidden.
If it is easy to get and how frequently you must use it.

There are several general types of contraception (outlined below), and often different kinds within each category. What they all have in common is that they prevent pregnancy, which means you can plan your life instead of leaving pregnancy and its responsibilities up to chance. Especially after an unplanned pregnancy, birth control can give you more control over your life.
How they differ is in how much attention and action using them demands from you, the sorts of side effects they bring, and how effective they are, and when they can be started.

Remember that side effects are different for each person, so a method that may be fine for your sister may be very uncomfortable for you. Also, effectiveness of contraception depends on using the methods correctly and consistently, and some are easier to use than others.

Your life circumstances, your body, and your likes and dislikes will determine which method is best for you. Nobody but you can decide that, and learning about the different methods can help you make an informed decision.
We Hope that we could Help you while use our App
the contraceptive vaginal ring is a flexible, soft, transparent ring that is inserted by the user for a 3-week period of continuous use followed by a ring-free week to allow menses.

▪ The ring is compressed and inserted into the vagina, behind the pubic bone. \n ▪ The vaginal ring is left in place for 3 weeks, then removed and discarded.\n ▪ The vaginal ring is not recommended for women with uterine prolapsed or lack of vaginal muscle tone.
The Method Chooser keeps your answers confidential — no one can find out how you have answered any of these questions.

The Method Chooser is a series of questions for you to answer about your experiences, your likes and dislikes, what you are comfortable doing to make your contraception work, and your health history. Based on your answers, it will recommend what might be your best options for birth control. (In this app, birth control, family planning, and contraception are all mean the same thing.) You can then learn more about each of these methods in the main section of the app, How each method works. And you can then talk with a trusted health worker about getting the contraception method you want.

There may be a lot of questions to answer, especially if you have tried several contraception methods in the past, or if you have health conditions which affect the type of contraceptives recommended for you. We encourage you to answer all of the questions, as this will improve the recommendations you receive.

Because condoms are the only method that prevents STIs, including HIV, they will almost always be one of the recommendations of the Method Chooser. While you have to consider all the different factors that will help you use birth control consistently and correctly, the option of condoms is almost always a good one. Think carefully about your risk for getting an STI before deciding that condoms are not for you.
If it can be started right away after childbirth, or after a miscarriage or abortion.

You might have other needs and concerns. For example: Will you be able to keep it private? If you have to go to a clinic regularly to get it, will the people there treat you respectfully? Are you breastfeeding? Do you have all the children you want? Do you never want children? Nobody knows what you want better than you.
How well it protects against STIs (Condoms are the only family planning method that also protects against STIs including HIV).

There are a lot of different methods you can use to prevent pregnancy. No one method is best for everyone and you should be free to choose the method you want. The best method for you is one that works and that you are most comfortable using.

Family planning is having the number of children you want, when you want them. This app explains the many safe, effective methods to prevent pregnancy. It includes a Method Chooser to help you determine which method is right for you or the person you are counseling. A section on Counseling can help you improve your skills. \n The right to decide when to get pregnant and when to prevent pregnancy is central to our right to health. People are healthier when they can decide for themselves when to have sex, and if and when to have children. Access to contraception enables us to make those decisions
What is most important to you when choosing a birth control method ?!
Select 3 things most important to you !
Able to get pregnant quickly after stopping the method
Can be kept secret from others (my parents or partner)
Don\'t need to interrupt sex to use it
Prevents pregnancy for 1 year or longer

Pills that contain the hormones estrogen and progestin. Estrogen and progesterone suppress FSH and LH production, so ovarian follicles do not mature and ovulation is inhibited. Take one pill everyday around the same time.
Pills that act in the same manner as the combination pills but contain only progestin. Progesterone cause thickening of the cervical mucus making penetration by spermatozoa is difficult.
The pills are started in 5th day of the cycle for 21 days continuously.
It is taken preferably at night and after meal.
If you have missed 1 pill, you should take the last pill you missed now, even if this means taking 2 pills in 1 day. Carry on taking the rest of the pack as normal.
If 2 pills are missing they are given in the next 2 days one in each day.
Contain progestin hormone to prevent pregnancy given every 3 months.
A single-rod progestin implant (Implanon) sub dermal used for 3-5 years.
Patch is placed on the abdomen, arm, or buttock. It needs to be changed every week. It contains the same active components as birth control pills but is absorbed through the skin.
It is a dome shaped rubber cup with a firm ring that covers the cervix.
How does the vaginal diaphragm work?

Diaphragms cover your cervix, which is the opening between your vagina and uterus. They create a barrier separating sperm ejaculated into your vagina during intercourse and your uterus. Vaginal diaphragms are used with spermicide. Spermicides are available as a foam, cream, gel, or suppository that you can apply to your diaphragm. Spermicide immobilizes sperm so they don’t reach your uterus.
•\tYou can put in a diaphragm or cap with spermicide any time before you have sex.
•\tThe diaphragm or cap needs to be left in place for at least 6 hours after sex.
A condom is a fine barrier which is rolled on to a man’s penis before sex. It is used as a barrier to stop sperm and infection passing between sexual partners. It is usually made of rubber.
Instruction for usage of Diagram and Sponge:
• Always empty the bladder prior to inserting it.
•\tInspect diaphragm for holes or tears by holding it up to a light source, or fill it with water and check for a leak.
•\tUses jell or cream in the dome and around the rim of the diaphragm.
•\tthe diaphragm can be inserted up to 6 hrs, prior to intercourse.
•\tHold the diaphragm between the thumb and fingers and compress it.
•\tFeel for the cervix through the diaphragm to make sure it is properly placed.
Effective barrier to sexually transmitted disease.
Small plastic device with copper sleeves, inserted through the vagina and cervix into the uterus.
Hormone-releasing IUD, the progesterone hormone is slowly released.
▪ Free copper and copper salts that have which have spermicidal effects.
▪ Never try to remove IUD by herself.
▪ Check every pad during her menstrual period.
▪ You should return 3 months. 6 months and 1 year for checkup.
▪ The women should feel the string of the IUD especially for first 3 months.
▪ Any signs of pregnancy should be reported because the danger of ectopic pregnancy.
Surgical family planning Methods for male and female
Fallopian tubes are occluded by cautery, clamping or blocking.
The procedure involves making a small incision into the scrotum and cutting the vas deferens, which carries sperm from the testes to the after vasectomy, semen no longer contains sperm.
